value: If you import the pprint module into your programs, you’ll have access to the pprint() and pformat() functions that will “pretty print” a dictionary’s values. This is helpful when you want a cleaner display of the items in a dictionary than what print() provides. Modify the previous characterCount.py program and save it as prettyCharacterCount.py.

import pprint
message = 'It was a bright cold day in April, and the clocks were striking'
thirteen.
count = {}

for character in message:
count.setdefault(character, 0)
count[character] = count[character] + 1

pprint.pprint(count)
This time, when the program is run, the output looks much cleaner, with the keys sorted.
